conclusion: To determine the proportionality constant k, we need to analyze the motion of the oil droplets under the influence of air resistance and the applied voltage.

Two spherical oil droplets, A and B, are located on the same vertical line. They both fall with a uniform velocity through a distance h1 within time t. At this moment, a voltage U is applied across the two plates (with the upper plate connected to the positive terminal).
The velocity of oil droplets during uniform motion when no voltage is applied is given by v1 = sqrt(2g(h1 + d)/m0).
The air resistance on spherical oil droplets during uniform motion is given by f = k m^(1/3)v, where k is the proportionality constant we need to find.
When a voltage U is applied across the plates, the droplets continue to fall with the same uniform velocity v1. The droplets are now moving upwards with a velocity v due to the applied voltage.

After merging with A, the droplets continue to move between the plates until they reach uniform velocity. The velocity of the droplets after merging with A is given by v = sqrt(2g(h1 + d)/m0) + sqrt(2g(h2 + d)/m0).
The final velocity of the droplets after merging with A is v = sqrt(2g(h1 + d)/m0) + sqrt(2g(h2 + d)/m0).
The final velocity of the droplets is the sum of the initial velocity and the velocity due to air resistance: v = v1 + f.
Substituting the expressions for v1 and f, we get v = sqrt(2g(h1 + d)/m0) + k m^(1/3)sqrt(2g(h2 + d)/m0).
Simplifying, we get v = sqrt(2g(h1 + d)/m0) + k sqrt(2g(h2 + d)/m0).
The proportionality constant k is k = v / sqrt(2g(h1 + d)/m0).
